paper_title: Non-synergistic photocatalysis of CO2-to-CO conversion by a binuclear complex of rigidly linking two cobalt catalytic centers

paragraphs.paragraph_text: A novel binuclear cobalt complex C1 of rigidly linking two Co(TPA)ClCl moieties at meta positions of a benzene was synthesized and characterized as a catalyst for homogeneous photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.Different from state-of-the-art binuclear catalyst catalyzing CO 2 reduction with a synergistic catalysis mechanism, C1 catalyses CO 2 -to-CO conversion independently at each cobalt catalytic center.At an optimal condition, system of C1 produced CO with a TON of 721 (based on C1, corrsoponding to TON 360 per cobalt center) and a high selectivity of 91.5.Electrochemistry and steady state spectroscopy studies revealed that a Co I Co I species, generated via successive photoinduced electron transfer from excited photosensitizer to C1, is the active species of CO 2 conversion.No synergistic effect of two cobalt centers exists for CO 2 reduction because of larger Co-Co distance and rigid structure of C1.

annotations.source: A novel binuclear cobalt complex C1 of rigidly linking two Co(TPA)ClCl moieties at meta positions of a benzene was synthesized and characterized as a catalyst for homogeneous photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.

paragraphs.paragraph_text: All reagents were analytic grade and used directly without further purification, except special note.All solvents and triethlyamine(TEA) were purchased from Sinopharm chmical.5-bromopicolinaldehyde, bis (pyridin-2-ylmethyl)amine (DPA), 1,3-diethylnylbenzene and 1,4-diethylnylbenzene were purchased from Adamas-beta.Pd(PPh 3 ) 4 was obtained from Energy chemical.Sodium triacetoxyborohydride(NaBH (AcO) 3 ) was obtained from Macklin.CoCl 2 6H 2 O was purchased from Acros.CO 2 (99.999),CO (99.99),N 2 (99.999),Ar (99.999) and CH 4 (99.99) were purchased from Huaerwen medical gas.Silica gel (200-300 mesh) was obtained from Qingdao Haiyang chemical. 1H NMR (400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (100 MHz) spectra were recorded on Bruker Advance III, and tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard in deuterated chloroform (CDCl 3 ).FT-IR spectra were performed on Bruker Invenio-R spectrometer.UV-vis absorption spectra were recorded with PerkinElmer Lambda 750 s spectrophotometer.Fluorescence Spectroscopy were performed on RF-5301PC and the excitaion wavelength was 400 nm.Electrospray ionization -mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) were conducted on Bruker microTOF II spectrometer.Elementral analysis were performed with Vario Micro cube. The generated CO and H 2 were quantitatively analyzed by GC (Techcomp GC7900) with FID and TCD, respectively, and argon was the carrier gas.Every value of TON was obtained from two parallel samples. Liquid products, such as formic acid, were not detected by ion chromatography (Metrohm IC 861).Hybrid functional PBE0 with dispersion corrections in revision three (D3BJ) was employed to describing dispersion interactions and the 6-31G basis set was used for hydrogen, carbon, cobalt and nitrogen atoms to optimal the geometry structures of C1. Cyclic voltammogram (CV) and constant potential coulometry were performed on CHI 660E electrochemistry workstation with threeelectrode system using a one-compartment cell.Pt wire and a nonaqueous Ag/AgNO 3 electrode were chosen as counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively.For CV, Glass carbon(GC) electrode was applied as working electrode.For constant potential coulometry, carbon rod was chosen as working electrode.The supporting electrolyte solution was 0.1 M n Bu 4 NPF 6 in CH 3 CN, and degassed with N 2 for 20 min before experiment.The concentrition of Co II complex was 0.5 mM. 1-(5-bromopyridin-2-yl)-N,N-bis(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)methanamine (TPA-Br) was synthesized following the procedure 32.5-bromopicolinaldehyde (800.0 mg, 4.30 mmol) and DPA (943.0 mg, 4.73 mmol) were dissolved in CH 3 CN (20.0 mL) in a 50 mL two-neck flask.After 30 min, NaBH(OAc) 3 (1.8g, 8.60 mmol) was added into the solution.The mixture was stirred for 24 h under N 2 atmosphere at room temperature.The solvent was removed by rotary evaporation.The residue was redissolved in CHCl 3 (100.0mL) and washed three times with saturated Na 2 CO 3 , followed by drying over Na 2 SO 4 .After filtered, filtrate was concentrated to get yellow oil and purified by column chromatography (silica gel) with dichloromethane/methanol (v/v, 30:1) as eluent.Yellowish solid was yielded (1.4 g, 3.79 mmol, 88 yield). 1 H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3 ) 8.58 (s, 1H), 8.54-8.55(d, J 4.24 Hz, 2H), 7.76-7.78(dd, J 2.04, 8.28 Hz, 1H), 7.64-7.68(m, 2H), 7.49-7.55(m, 3H), 7.14-7.17(m, 2H), 3.85-3.88(d, 6H).FT-IR (KBr pellet): 3051, 3008, 2821, 1589, 1470, 1433, 764, 507 cm -1 (Fig. S5). L1 and L2 were synthesized through Sonogashira coupling reaction.For L1, TPA-Br (500.0 mg, 1.35 mmol), 1,3-diethylnylbenzene (74.4 mg, 0.59 mmol), Pd(PPh 3 ) 4 (60.0 mg, 0.05 mmol) and TEA (5.0 mL) were added into 50 mL three-neck flask and dissolved in anhydrous THF (15.0 mL).The mixed solution was heated to reflux for 12 h.After reaction, the solvent was removed by rotary evaporation.The residue was purified by column chromatography (silica gel), eluented with dichloromethane/methanol (v/v, 15:1) to produce a cream color solid (304.0 mg, 0.43 mmol, 73.3 yield). 1 C1 and C2 were synthesized by the following procedure, respectively.L1 (208.0 mg, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in CH 3 OH(10.0mL) in a 25 mL flask.the methanol solution of CoCl 2 6H 2 O (133.2 mg, 0.56 mmol) was added into the flask, and stirred for one hour.Diethyl ether (30.0 mL) was added to the reaction solution and precipitate produced.After contrifugation and drying, Blackish green solid was obtained (C1, 146.5 mg, 0.15 mmol, 51.4 yield).L2 (80.0 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dissolved in CH 3 OH (5.0 mL) in a 25 mL flask, CoCl 2 6H 2 O (47.0 mg, 0.20 mmol, dissolved in methanol (2.0 mL) was added into the flask, and stirred for one hour.Diethyl ether (20.0 mL) was added to the reaction solution and precipitate produced.The precipitate was collected by contrifugation and dried to produce C2 (backish green solid, 42.1 mg, 0.08 mmol, 40.5 yield).ESI-MS (): C1 -Cl , m/z 925.0879(calc.m/z 925.0949)(Fig. S3), and C2 -Cl , m/z 484.0823(calc.m/z 484.0864)(Fig. S4).FT-IR (KBr pellet): for C1, 3055, 3028, 2912, 2216, 1606, 1481, 1436, 768 cm -1 (Fig. S5).For C2, 3055, 3030, 2912, 2222, 1608, 1498, 1438, 762 cm -1 (Fig. S6 The experiments of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction were performed in Pyrex tubes.Cobalt complex and Ir(ppy) 3 were put into the tube with certain concentration and the total volume of photocatalytic solution was 5.0 mL (the volume ratio of DMF/TEA was 4:1).Before irradiation, the sample was sealed and degassed with CO 2 for 25 min and then CH 4 (500 L) was injected as internal standard.The sample was irradiated with blue LED-photoreactor ( max 450 nm) at ambient temperature.

paragraphs.paragraph_text: The binuclear complex C1 and its mononuclear analogue were designed and synthesized, respectively.The complex C1 contains two Co(TPA)ClCl moieties, as Co(TPA)ClCl is one of the most effective CoN 4 -type catalysts for CO 2 reduction 23,24.To avoid synergistic effect of two cobalt centers in C1 for CO 2 conversion like the successful example of binuclear Co cryptate complex reported by Lu et al. 2526272829 we covalently linked two Co(TPA)ClCl moieties to meta positions of a benzene by two rigid alkynyl groups.Firstly, two ligands, L1 or L2, were synthesized by Sonogashira coupling reaction of linking brominated tris (2-pyridylmethyl)amine (TPA-Br) to 1,3-diethylnylbenzene or phenylacetylene, respectively (Scheme 2).They were characterized by 1 H NMR, 13 C NMR, electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) and FT-IR spectra (Supplementary Information, SI).C1 and C2 were obtained by the reaction of CoCl 2 6H 2 O with corresponding ligand in methanol at room temperature, respectively.The ESI-MS spectra show the ion peak at m/z 925.0879 and 484.0823 (Figs.S3 andS4), which match well with C1 -Cl and C2 -Cl .UV-vis adsorption spectra of C1 and C2 (Fig. 1a) in DMF show the absorption of the ligand at 292 nm and 291 nm, respectively.Absorptions at 400-700 nm of C1 and C2 are ascribed to d-d transition of the metal center 23,24.The molar extinction coefficient () of the absorption peaks of C1 are twofold of those of C2 at the same concentration.These results demonstrate that the successful synthesis of C1 and C2.Structure optimization based on calculations revealed that the distance between two Co centers in C1 is 14.77 A (Fig. 1b). To investigate the photocatalytic activity of C1 and C2, systematic photocatalytic CO 2 reduction experiments were carried out.The system was established in a CO 2 -staturated DMF/TEA mixed solution (V DMF / V TEA 4/1, V total 5.00 mL) and irradiated for 5 h under blue LED lamp ( max 450 nm).At a condition of (sample E and F, Fig. 2a).The values of CO production selectivity of these samples are in the range of 93.5-97.3.At higher PS/Cat.ratios, the turnovers based on cobalt center of C1 are lower than those of C2.Presumably, two cobalt centers in C1 cannot be fully reduced by excited Ir(ppy) 3 at a lower PS/Cat.ratio if a synergistic catalysis mechanism can be excluded (discussed below).At a higher PS/Cat.ratio, two cobalt centers in C1 works to afford CO.However, steric effect emerging in the course of CO 2 reduction at two cobalt centers in C1 is considered to slightly lower catalytic efficiency of each cobalt center.This may explain the lower TON Co of C1 than that of C2 at a higher PS/ Cat.ratio. At the optimal condition of PS/Cat. 40 (PS 2.00 10 -4 M, C1 C2 5.00 10 -6 M), long time photocatalytic experiments were performed.Two systems of using C1 and C2 as a catalyst, respectively, continuously produced CO with high selectivity.At the initial stage, an induction period was observed, which is probably due to structural changes of the catalyst 333435.The C1 and C2 system produced CO with TON C1 721 (TON Co 360) and TON C2 369, respectively, after irradiation of 60 h.While C1 exhibits the almost similar catalytic activity to the mononuclear analogue C2, evalued by the cobalt centers.The C1-system maintains almost 2 times CO production of C2-system throughout the entire photocatalysis.The CO production selectivity of the two system is 91.5 for C1 and 91.4 for C2.The catalytic activity of CO production dramatically decreased after 40 h of photocatalysis, indicating at least one component in the system decomposed.After finishing the long time photocatalysis (60 h), extra Ir (ppy) 3 (2.00 10 -4 M) was added into the C1-system and the sample was irradiated for another 20 h.TON C1 241 (TON Co 120) for CO production was obtained.This result indicates that catalyst C1 was still robust.The main reason of CO production ceasing is the decomposition of Ir(ppy) 3 . To gain insights into the system, mechanism studies were performed.Cyclic voltammogram of C1 and C2 were conducted in DMF and CH 3 CN.Both complex C1 and C2 show reductive waves upon reductive scan under N 2 atomsphere in DMF or CH 3 CN (Fig. 3 and Fig. S9).The reduction peaks are more identifiable in DMF.For the complex C1, three successive reduction peaks emerge at -1.47 V, -1.61 V, and -1.91 V (Fig. 3a).For the complex C2, two reductiion peaks at -1.46 V and -1.89 V were observed (Fig. 3b).At the same complex concentration (0.5 mM) in CH 3 CN, the current density of C1 increase to 0.50 mA cm -2 at -1.59 V, which is two-times higher than that of C2 (0.25 mA cm -2 at -1.55 V).Constant-potential coulometry of C1 at -1.59 V gave a current decay to zero after 40000 s with n 2 (Fig. S10), demonstrating every molecule of C1 consumes two electrons at this potential.Based on above results and previous reports 1718192021222324, the reductive peaks at -1.47 V, -1.61 V, and -1.91 V of C1 are assigned to Co II Co II /Co II Co I , Co II Co I / Co I Co I , and ligand-centred reduction, respectively.The reductive peaks at -1.46 V and -1.89 V of C2 are correspondingly assigned to Co II /Co I and ligand-centred reduction, respectively.Under CO 2 atmosphere, both C1 and C2 showed an enhanced current density at the cobalt-centered reductive waves in comparison to those of under N 2 atmosphere (Figs. 3 andS9).Previous studies had been revealed that Co I species of CoN 4 complexes is the active species for CO 2 binding 171819202122.The current enhancement of C1 and C2 in CO 2 atmosphere is attributed to the electrocatalysis of CO 2 by Co I species generated by C1 and C2.The current density of C1 (0.70 mA cm -2 ) in CO 2 atmosphere is also two-fold of C2 (0.32 mA cm -2 ) in CV analysis in CH 3 CN (Figure S9).This indicates each of Co I species in C1 binding a CO 2 . To investigate the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process between Ir(ppy) 3 and two cobalt complexes, C1 and C2, a series of emission quenching experiments were operated.The emission at 515 nm of Ir (ppy) 3 in degassed DMF (excitation wavelength 400 nm) can be effectively quenched by successive addition of C1 or C2 (Cat. 13 M -110 M) into the solution.According emission lifetime (1.47 s) of Ir (ppy) 3 recorded in literature, 18 the quenching rate constant k q for C1 and C2 is 4.37 10 9 M -1 s -1 and 3.46 10 9 M -1 s -1 , respectively (Fig. S7) 1718192021222324.The k q of C1 and C2 is not a two-fold relationship because the concentrations of cobalt complexes increase gradually in these quenching experiments.However, the k q of C1 is still showing a 1.3-fold improvement compared with that of C2.At an optimal PS/ Cat.ratio, a 4.92 and 2.08 emission area of Ir(ppy) 3 (5.00 10 -6 M) can be quenched by adding C1 (1.00 10 -3 M) and C2 (1.00 10 -3 M), respectively, with a same concentration (Fig. 4), the quenching efficiency of C1 is more than two-fold of C2 at this condition.This quenching efficiency improves to 3.51 by doubling C2 concentration (2.00 10 -3 M), which is still less efficiency than that of C1.Presumably, C1 having two cobalt centers improves local concentration at a molecular level, this leads more efficiency of C1 than that of C2 for quenching even at a same cobalt concentration.The reductive quenching of Ir(ppy) 3 by TEA was also conducted, it follows Stern-Volmer behaviour well with a k q of 1.71 10 7 M -1 s -1 (Fig. S8).The k q of TEA is far lower than that of C1 or C2, indicating a more effective oxidation quenching of Ir(ppy) 3 by the cobalt catalyst dominates in the photocatalytic system. The emission quenching between Ir(ppy) 3 and cobalt complexes is attributed PET from excited Ir(ppy) 3 to cobalt complexes, C1 or C2, because of no obvious overlap between the emission spectrum of Ir (ppy) 1) 40,41. Taking all results described above, a general mechanism of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction by C1 can be proposed.During photocatalysis, Ir (ppy) 3 is firstly excited upon visible light irradiation.The excited Ir (ppy) 3 molecules react with one C1 to generate a Co I Co I species in C1 via two successive PET processes.In consideration of the rigid structure and the large Co-Co distance in C1, the synergistic effect of two Co centers binding and stabilizing one CO 2 in the course of photocatalysis can be excluded 252627282930,31,40,41.Due to the large distance between two cobalt center in C1, each Co I species in C1 binds a CO 2 and subsequently convert it to CO (Scheme 3).In this process, steric effect between two cobalt centers probably exists and thus slightly affects catalytic activity of each cobalt center in C1.The CO 2 -to-CO conversion mechanism of Co I species had been studied and clarified based on DFT calculations in documents 171819202122.The Co I Co I species is the active species for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.The PS is reduced to PS by a sacrificial electron donor, TEA, which abundantly exists in the system 42.In this catalytic cycle, the complex C1 catalyses CO 2 -to-CO conversion by two catalytic sites independently, two metal centers are fully used for CO 2 transformation.

paragraphs.paragraph_text: In conclusion, a binuclear cobalt complex C1 containing two Co (TPA)ClCl moieties was synthesized.The two cobalt catalytic centers with large distance are rigidly linked at meta positions of a benzene.The C1 showed high activity, selectivity and stability for CO production in a photocatalytic CO 2 reduction system of using Ir(ppy) 3 as a Electrochemical and photocatalytic data of C1 and C2. a Catalyst. E red /V b G/eV The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. PS/Cat. 10 (PS 1.00 10 -4 M, C1 C2 1.00 10 -5 M), two catalysts exhibited same activity for CO production (sample A and B in Fig. 2a), TON C1 48 (TON Co 24), TON C2 48.By increasing the PS/Cat.ratio to 20 (PS 1.00 10 -4 M, C1 C2 5.00 10 -6 M), TON C1 increased to 77 (TON Co 38, sample C, Fig. 2a).However, TON C2 was 42 (sample D, Fig. 2a), which doesn't change much.Further increasing the PS/Cat.ratio to 40 (PS 2.00 10 -4 M, C1 C2 5.00 10 -6 M), TON C1 and TON C2 increased to 85 (TON Co 43) and 66, respectively Scheme 2. The synthetic routes and structures of L1, L2, C1 and C2. Fig. 1.(a) UV-vis absorption spectra of C1, C2 (2.00 10 -5 M) and L1, L2 (1.00 10 -5 M) in DMF.(b) The optimal structure of C1 calculated by hybrid functional PBEO with dispersion corrections in revision three (D3BJ). Fig. 2. (a) A: C1 1.00 10 -5 M, Ir(ppy) 3 1.00 10 -4 M. B: C2 1.00 10 -5 M, Ir(ppy) 3 1.00 10 -4 M. C: C1 5.00 10 -6 M, Ir(ppy) 3 1.00 10 -4 M. D: C2 5.00 10 -6 M, Ir(ppy) 3 1.00 10 -4 M. E: C1 5.00 10 -6 M, Ir(ppy) 3 2.00 10 -4 M. F: C2 5.00 10 -6 M, Ir(ppy) 3 2.00 10 -4 M. All samples were set in a TEA/DMF mixed solution (V DMF : V TEA 4 : 1, total volume 5.00 mL) and irradiated for 5 h.(b) Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction; C1 C2 5.00 10 -6 M, Ir(ppy) 3 2.00 10 -4 M in a DMF/TEA mixed solution (V DMF : V TEA 4 : 1, total volume 5.00 mL) and irradiated for 60 h. Fig. 3. Cyclic voltammograms of C1 (a) and C2 (b) in 0.1 mol L -1 n Bu 4 NPF 6 /DMF solution degassed with N 2 or CO 2 for 20 min, respectively.The concentration of cobalt complex was 0.5 mmol L -1 . 3 and absorption spectra of cobalt complexes as well as efficient photocatalysis.According to documented excited state redox potential (E -1.73V vs. SCE) of Ir(ppy) 3 in CH 3 CN and the reduction peaks potential of C1,23,24,36-39 the free energy change values of the PET are estimated as -0.26 eV and -0.12 eV for the Co II Co II /Co II Co I and Co II Co I /Co I Co I reductions, respectively.For Co II /Co I reductioin of C2, this value is esitmataed as -0.27 eV.These results indicate that either succesive two PET steps of C1 or one PET of C2 are exothermic (Table Fig. 4. Fluorescence quenching of Ir(ppy) 3 with C1 and C2, respectively.Ir (ppy) 3 5.00 10 -6 M in DMF with 3.0 mL.C1 (5.00 10 -6 M in DMF) was injected to Ir(ppy) 3 with 48 L.C2 (5.00 10 -6 M in DMF) was injected to Ir (ppy) 3 with 48 L and 96 L. photosensitizer and TEA as a sacrificial electron donor.TON C1 and selectivity for CO production of 721 (TON Co 360) and 91.5, respectively, were achieved by C1 after 60 h of photocatalysis.Binuclear complex C1 exhibits almost similar catalytic activity to the mononuclear analogue C2, evalued by the cobalt centers.Electrochemistry and steady state spectroscopy studies demonstrated that two Co II centers in C1 can be successively reduced to form a Co I Co I species via PET.The Co I Co I species as catalytic sites for CO 2 reduction catalyse CO 2 -to-CO conversion independently during photocatalysis.CRediT authorship contribution statement Wu Xia: Writingoriginal draft, Investigation, Data curation, Investigation, Validation.Ying-Yi Ren: Investigation.Jing Liu: Investigation.Bo-Yi Deng: Investigation.Feng Wang: Conceptualization, Funding acquisition, Writingreview editing, Supervision. H NMR(400 MHz, CDCl 3 ) (ppm) 8.68(s, 2H), 8.54-8.55(d, J 3.08 Hz, 4H), 7.77-7.78(dd, J 1.40 Hz, 1H), 7.73 (s, 1H), 7.65-7.68(m, 4H), 7.60 (s, 1H), 7.61 (s, 1H), 7.56-7.57(d, 4H), 7.51-7.52(m, 2H), 7.35-7.38(t, J 5.20 Hz,1H), 7.15-7.17(m, 4H), 3.90-3.91(d, 12H). 13C NMR(100 MHz, CDCl 3 ) (ppm) 159.24, 159.18, 151.63, 149.26, 139.00, 136.56, 134.78, 131.79, 128.74, 123.27, 123.16, 122.54, 122.19, 118.40, 91.31, 87.01, 60.36, 60.09, 45.91.ESI-MS(): M Na , m/z 725.3265(calc.m/z 725.3112).M H , m/z 703.3322(calc.m/z 703.3293for M H ) (Fig. S1).FT-IR(KBr pellet): 3011, 2821, 2210, 1589, 1483, 1434, 768 cm -1 (Fig. S5).Elemental analysis: calcd.() for C 46 H 38 N 8 (L1): C 78.61, H 5.45, N 15.94; found: C 78.86, H 5.40, N 15.74.Following the synthetic route of L1, phenylacetylene were used instead of 1,3-diethylnylbenzene to prepare L2.For L2 (light yellow solid, 190.4 mg, 0.49 mmol, 60.4 yield). 1 H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3 ) (ppm) 8.68 (s, 1H), 8.54-8.55(d, 2H), 7.75-7.79(m, 1H), 7.64-7.69(m, 2H), 7.49-7.60(m, 6H), 7.35-7.37(m, 2H), 7.14-7.17(t, 2H), 3.84-3.90(m, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl 3 ) (ppm) 159.13, 158.74, 151.47, 149.13, 138.85, 136.45, 131.64, 128.69, 128.42, 123.03, 122.38, 122.07, 118.62, 92.25, 86.12, 60.21, 59.96, 52.97, 47.75.ESI-KBr pellet): 3008, 2922, 2823, 2192, 1469, 1433, 1365, 761 cm -1 (Fig. S6).Elemental analysis: calcd.() for C 26 H 22 N 4 (L2): C 79.97, H 5.68, N 14.35; found: C 80.29, H 5.48, N 14.22. MS(): M H , m/z 391.1929(calc.m/z 391.1918for M H ).M Na , m/z 413.1768(calc.m/z 413.1742)(Fig. S2).FT-IR ( ).
